The publication of an updated list of laws and regulations on tobacco control and information about the enforcement of laws on tobacco control as well as pertinent jurisprudence on the website of the the federal ministry of health is available.

Azerbaijan Global Youth Tobacco Survey (GYTS) – 2011 was conducted by support of the WHO/CDC. It was a school-based survey of students in grades 8 through 10. A two-stage cluster sample design was used to produce representative data for Azerbaijan. At the first stage schools were selected with probability proportional to enrollment size. At the second stage classes were randomly selected and all students in selected classes were eligible to participate. A total of 2 047 students participated in the Azerbaijan GYTS of which 2 018 were ages 13 to 15 years. The overall response rate of all students surveyed was 73.2%.
In 2011 Azerbaijan implemented National Survey on Risk Factors for Chronic Noncommunicable Diseases (STEPS metodology). The sampling frame was all population of Azerbaijan aged 18 years and above with the sample size of 2400.

The data collection and data entry for GYTS 2013 was recently completed. A representative from the Ministry of Health will be attending the global data analysis meeting in Tunisia in May following this the national report will be finalised.

1. Addictiveness and Attractiveness of Tobacco Additives Scientific Committee on Emerging and Newly Identified Health Risks SCENIHR 2010
See http://ec.europa.eu/health/scientific_committees/emerging/docs/scenihr_o_031.pdf
2. Effectiveness of Tax and Price Policies for Tobacco Control - IARC Handbooks of Cancer Prevention Tobacco Control Volume 14 2011 
See http://apps.who.int/bookorders/anglais/detart1.jsp?sesslan=1&codlan=1&codcol=76&codcch=30
Co- funded by PPACTE (Pricing Policies and Control of Tobacco in Europe). PPACTE was a collaborative 3-year project being funded by the European Commission''s Seventh Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development (FP7)
See http://www.ppacte.eu/
3. A project co- funded by the EU and it''s 16 participating countries the so called Public Information Tobacco Control (PITOC) has resulted in websites with fact sheets that inform the public on the general and tobacco industry use of tobacco additives as well as their harmful health effects. 
See http://www.rivm.nl/en/Topics/Topics/T/Tobacco/PITOC_factsheets
4. ''Developing methodologies to reduce inequalities in the determinants of health'' Prof Ken Judge 2011- 2015. This study was financed under the 7th EU Framework Programme. Inequalities in smoking are specifically addressed.
See https://tuhat.halvi.helsinki.fi/portal/en/projects/eu-7th-framework-de(4b42c1c2-db65-4d07-8ee2-9cde529ec7a3).html
5. TobTaxY (Making Tobacco Tax Trendy) was a project that aims to provide tobacco control advocates in Europe with training and expertise on tobacco tax and illicit trade issues by bringing together practical expert knowledge and disseminating its use in the field. The project has received funding from the European Union in the framework of the Health Programme. 
 See http://www.smokefreepartnership.eu/tobtaxy
column4:
The EU Health Programme includes the possibility to fund research and training projects envisaged by Articles 20.1(a) and (b) of the FCTC. 
The EU routinely collects data on key tobacco-control indicators (including those listed in Article 20.3(a) in particular via the European Health Interview Survey (EHIS) the European Household Survey (EHS) and special Eurobarometer surveys on tobacco.

El IHADFA se mantiene alerta ante la vigilancia del cumplimiento de la Ley Especial para el Control del Tabaco y su Reglamentación y anuente ante la necesidad de intercambio de información a nivel nacional como internacional. Se han atendido comunicaciones de intercambio de información sobre el control de productos de tabaco entre el IHADFA y la Direcciòn Ejecutiva de Ingresos DEI y otras instituciones del Estado

The summary of the data gained during the control of complying with smoking prohibitions needs to comply with qualitative and quantitative requirements. For this purpose. the development of the new software regarding the control of compliance with the law. which is fitting to the registration system had finished.

column4:
The STEP Survey is currently conducted for the 2nd time for Tonga which is nationally representative. The 1st one was conducted in 2004.
Our next national Census would be carried out next month in which information on tobacco consumption is incorporated into the Census in one question asking every person 6 yrs and above whether they smoke tobacco or cigarettes on a daily basis.
The GYTS was also conducted last year 2010 but the results/report of that survey is not yet officially published.
